title: Adrianna Martinez
text:
Welcome!
Hello and welcome to my page! My name is Adrianna Martinez and I am completing my third year of undergrad at the University of California Santa Barbara. I am pursuing a Bachelor‚Äôs of Science in Environmental Studies with a minor in Earth Science.¬†
I grew up in the heart of Las Vegas, NV, where my passions for the outdoors and habitat preservation began to flourish, driving my academic and career goals today. I have always loved various outdoor activities such as off-roading, skiing, tennis, soccer, camping, and running.¬†
Currently, I am working with Santa Barbara Channelkeeper, monitoring fishing, boating, and recreational activities in MPA‚Äôs along the coast. You can also find me at the bowling alley, serving kids birthday parties, corporate events, and the bowling regulars.¬†¬†
With a new found love for rocks and plate tectonics, I hope to pursue a career path to becoming a geologist!


Education
Environmental Studies B.S. and Earth Science Minor (2026) | University of California, Santa Barbara
Faith Lutheran High School (2022)

title: About Me
text:
I created this site to share my academic work and personal interests. Below are two of my favorite hobbies!
Growing up in the desert, my family often spent time off-roading, dirt bike riding, and camping. We would travel to the deserts of Utah, hit trails in South Lake Tahoe, and venture into the red rocks of the Las Vegas valley.¬†

   

I love drawing and painting! I began practicing visual art in middle school and have expanded my artistic abilities over the years to watercolor, oil and acrylic, printmaking, charcoal and graphite, and ceramics. I love surrealism, incorporating landscapes, portraits, and vibrant colors into my works. Here you can see some of my favorite pieces and the inspiration behind each one.




Growing and Dying Acrylic on stretched canvas; a play on idealism amidst environmental crisis‚Äîthe cycle of hope, fear, and mourning.





Milk & Honey Mixed media painting exploring heaven, the realm where milk and honey flows.





Natives A study of edible plants native to Santa Barbara area; assisted by indigenous knowledge.





Desert Sun Inspired by desert camping trips; commissioned by family friends.





Laying Lamb A soft-toned watercolor portrait of a lamb; a symbol of softness, vulnerability, and trust.





My Doves Surrealistic depiction of a dove; a meditation on peace and release.

title: Courses
text: A selection of coursework that has shaped my interests in environmental science, geology, and sustainable resource management. Projects linked below will become available soon!

title: Courses
text:
Environmental Science Courses

ENV S 154: GIS for Environmental Applications
Explored how Geographic Information Systems (GIS) help analyze and communicate spatial patterns in environmental systems.
Project: Spatial analysis of groundwater contamination in California due to agriculture and ranching.
‚û°Ô∏è View Project (coming soon)



ENV S 115: Energy and the Environment
Covered energy extraction, consumption, justice, economics, and policy.
Project: Policy memo on sustainable lithium extraction in the Imperial Valley.
‚û°Ô∏è Read the memo (coming soon)



ENV S 140: Ecology and Management of Wildfire
Analyzed wildfire impacts on ecosystems, climate, and management strategies.
Included field trips to Sedgwick Reserve and Los Padres National Forest.
Project: Research paper on cultural burning and fire regimes in Australia.
‚û°Ô∏è Read the paper (coming soon)



ENV S 193GW: Groundwater Analysis
Studied groundwater hydrology, aquifer dynamics, and California groundwater policy.



ENV S 193DS: Stats for Environmental Science
Applied statistics to environmental datasets using R.
Project: Personal data study on productivity patterns over time.
‚û°Ô∏è See project (coming soon)
This website was also built during this course!

title: Courses
text:
üåç Earth Science Courses

EARTH 18: Field Studies
Field course exploring the geology of Joshua Tree and the Salton Sea during a 4-day field trip.



EARTH 2: Principles of Physical Geology
Introduction to Earth‚Äôs surface and interior processes.
Included a one-day field trip to the Santa Ynez Mountains.

title: Courses
text:
Upcoming Courses

ENV S 172: Waste Management
Covers sustainable waste systems, recycling, composting, incineration, and landfilling.


EARTH 111: Principles of Paleontology
Studies the structure and evolution of the biosphere through the fossil record.


EARTH 114: Geomaterials
Examines the chemistry and structure of the Earth‚Äôs crust, mantle, and core.


ENV S 95: Restoration Skills
Hands-on ecological restoration techniques including site planning, species management, and habitat monitoring.
